Description: Egyptian terracotta model of a dramatic mask. A fragment of a model of a dramatic mask, presumably tragic, but perhaps of a Satyr. Part only of its left side remains: a prominent nose and wide eye, a fierce eyebrow and a pointed ear, an open mouth drawn down at the corner, and straight radiating hair. The eyeball is pierced, and there is a hole through the ear. This hole and its lost companion were probably used to pin or hang it on a wall. The back is plain. Pushed into one-piece mould, then Red-brown slip added on front. Red-brown Nile silt with abundant fine gold mica and white inclusions.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Findspot: Found/Acquired: Town (Naukratis), Site 95 (Petrie), the terracotta workshop, at the eastern edge of the town
Curator's comments: From Site 95 terracottas workshop (Petrie et al. 1886, 45). Similar parallel dated 3rd century AD (Fischer 1994, no. 351). Another example from a 2nd century BC context at Naukratis (Leonard 2001, pl. 3.2). Fischer, J. 1994. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten aus Ägypten. Die Sammlungen Sieglin und Schreiber. Dresden, Leipzig, Stuttgart, Tübingen. Tübingen: Wasmuth. Leonard, A. (ed.) 2001. Ancient Naukratis: Excavations at a Greek Emporium, vol. II: The Excavations at Kom Hadid, ASOR.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3567)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.317) (Phase 1)
